text: Let me share a story from when I was twenty-one years old.
keypoint: Introducing a story from age twenty-one

text: I was living in a small apartment near the city center. I had just started my first job. And uh I was working as a graphic designer.
keypoint: Starting life as a young graphic designer in the city

text: My father, who was recovering from a surgery, hadn't been out in – in uh – well I'd say about eight months. He had to use a wheelchair to get around.
keypoint: Father recovering from surgery and using a wheelchair

text: The only person there with him during the day was a kind neighbor, a lady in her sixties. My younger sister was away at college – so it was just my dad and the neighbor lady at home during the day.
keypoint: Father cared for by neighbor while sister is away

text: One day, I got this strong feeling while I was at work. It told me: "If you go to the nearby park during your lunch break and pray for your father's recovery, he'll start to improve."
keypoint: A strong feeling urges a prayer for father’s recovery

text: I looked around my office. I didn't see anyone nearby.
keypoint: Checking for privacy in the office

text: So, I went to the park during my break and found a quiet spot there. That feeling came back again.
keypoint: Going to the park and feeling the urge again

text: I looked around once more. I still didn't see anyone nearby but I decided to take a chance.
keypoint: Looking around and deciding to take a chance

text: I wasn't too far from my office, maybe a ten-minute walk. I found a bench to sit on and closed my eyes – uh – uh – that feeling came back once more. I just took a deep breath.
keypoint: Finding a bench, feeling the urge, and preparing to pray

text: I was sitting under a big oak tree now. I looked up at the branches above me. Nobody was around. And uh I said to myself, well now,
keypoint: Sitting under an oak, reflecting on prayer’s power

text: I had been taught that prayers can make a difference. And that it doesn't hurt to try. I knew I wasn't perfect, but I wanted to help my dad. I'd admit that to anyone. But I was willing to give it a try.
keypoint: Belief in prayer and desire to help father

text: I looked around one more time and then I closed my eyes and said a quiet prayer.
keypoint: Looking around, closing eyes, and praying quietly

text: I whispered, "God, I don't know if you're listening. But I ask you to please help my father recover. So he can regain his independence and enjoy life again."
keypoint: Praying for father’s recovery and independence

text: I opened my eyes and went back to work.
keypoint: Finishing prayer and returning to work

text: Suddenly, I received a text message from my father. It said, "I just took a few steps with my walker."
keypoint: Father texts about taking steps with walker

text: I – I couldn't believe it. It felt like a sign that my prayer had been heard.
keypoint: Amazement and feeling prayer was answered

text: I rushed home after work and saw my father standing in the living room with the help of his walker. He hadn't been able to do that in months without assistance. And there he was, taking small steps.
keypoint: Rushing home and witnessing father’s progress

text: That was the turning point in his recovery. He continued to improve and regained most of his mobility within a year.
keypoint: Father’s recovery accelerates over the year

text: It's been, what, six or seven years since then? My father is now able to walk without any assistance. He's living life to the fullest, even in his seventies.
keypoint: Years later, father walks unaided and enjoys life
